{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19503,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chaenostoma hispidum, commonly known as Sutera, requires moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the active growing season in spring and summer, you might need to water it more frequently. Make sure the pot has drainage holes to prevent the roots from sitting in water, which can lead to root rot. Reduce watering during the fall and winter months, allowing the soil to dry slightly more between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chaenostoma hispidum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It will do best in a location that receives full sun to part shade, ideally with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. However, in excessively hot climates, providing some afternoon shade will protect the plant from intense sun exposure, which can cause leaf scorch. When grown indoors, placing it near a south or west-facing window ensures it receives adequate light. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chaenostoma hispidum is essential to encourage bushier growth and to enhance blooming. Trim back any leggy or overgrown stems frequently, particularly in early spring before the plant starts its active growing season. Removing dead or faded flowers regularly, a process known as deadheading, will also promote new blooms. Additionally, you can pinch back the tips of new growth to encourage a fuller, more compact shape. Avoid heavy pruning during the dormant period in winter. A balanced approach to pruning will keep your Sutera healthy and flourishing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bristle Skunkbush","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Bristle Skunkbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Chaenostoma hispidum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's essential to keep the soil consistently moist but well-drained, ensuring that it doesn't become waterlogged. During the growing season, water the plant when the topsoil feels dry to touch. In the winter months, reduce watering frequency, allowing the soil to dry out a bit more between waterings. Overwatering or allowing the roots to sit in water can lead to root rot, so make sure excess water can drain away efficiently."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cassine peragua thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. It is quite adaptable but performs best with at least four to six hours of direct sunlight per day. If grown in areas with very intense afternoon sun, providing some light shade can prevent leaf scorch. When grown indoors or under diminished light conditions, it may not bloom as profusely. Ensure that if it's a potted plant, it is rotated regularly for even sunlight exposure on all sides."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cassine peragua is generally done to maintain shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts just above a node or a healthy bud. Regular pruning helps in promoting better air circulation and light penetration, encouraging a dense, healthy growth. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the plant; minimal shaping is often sufficient for this shrub."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Saffron","description":"Cassine peragua, also known as Cape saffron, bastard saffron and forest spoonwood, is a medium-sized tree with fragrant flowers, decorative fruits and a saffron-coloured trunk. In Yucatán (one region where the bullhorn acacia thrives) it is called "subín", in Panamá the locals call them "cachito" (little horn). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19404,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tetragonia decumbens, commonly known as the dune spinach, prefers well-draining sandy or gravelly soils and does not require frequent watering due to its drought-tolerant nature. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, aiming to water once every two weeks or when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch, depending on your climate and season. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. During hot and dry periods, you can increase watering slightly, but be cautious not to leave the soil soggy. Rainwater or distilled water is preferred, if available."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tetragonia decumbens thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight can lead to less vigorous growth and decreased flower production. If grown indoors, place it near a sunny window with southern or western exposure to ensure it receives sufficient light. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade might be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching. Adequate sunlight is crucial for maintaining its dense, green foliage and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Tetragonia decumbens involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage new growth. While the plant doesn't require heavy pruning, regular trimming can help control its spread and shape. Pinch back the tips of the plant to promote bushier growth and to prevent it from becoming leggy. Perform pruning in the growing season, typically in spring and early summer, when the plant exhibits active growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant or spreading diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Coast Seacoral","description":"Tetragonia decumbens (dune spinach or sea spinach) is a coastal shrub, native to southern Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Coast Seacoral"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tetragonia decumbens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, water the plant regularly to keep the soil slightly moist but not waterlogged. In the winter months, the plant enters a period of dormancy and watering should be reduced significantly to prevent root rot. Always ensure that the topsoil is dry before watering again, and avoid overhead watering to reduce the risk of fungal diseases. As a drought-tolerant species, it can also withstand dry spells, making it ideal for low-maintenance gardens."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brachylaena neriifolia thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight a day for optimal growth and flowering. Planting it in a location with ample sunlight will stimulate healthy foliage and enhance its ornamental appeal. However, in extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. If grown in more shaded conditions, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ensuring the right balance of light will result in a robust and attractive plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Brachylaena neriifolia is essential to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Thinning the plant by cutting back some of the older stems at the base will promote air circulation and prevent overcrowding. Light pruning can also be done throughout the year to maintain the desired height and shape. Avoid heavy pruning, as it may affect flowering and plant vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Water White-Alder","description":"Brachylaena neriifolia, commonly known as the Cape silver oak, water white alder or waterwitels, is a small tree which is native to river valleys in southern Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Water White-Alder"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Brachylaena neriifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Always use well-draining soil and ensure excess water can escape from the pot to avoid waterlogged roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mammillaria meiacantha thrives in bright, direct sunlight. Ideally, it should receive 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown indoors, a south-facing window is best to ensure adequate light exposure. Insufficient light can result in elongated growth and poor health. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent sunburn. Gradually acclimate the plant to direct sun if moving it from a less sunny location, as sudden changes in light intensity can cause stress or damage to the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mammillaria meiacantha is usually minimal and consists mainly of removing dead or damaged plant material. Occasionally, offset removal helps maintain plant appearance and encourages healthier growth. Use sterilized tools to prevent spreading infections. Handle the plant carefully to avoid damage to its dense spines. Periodically checking for and removing any debris accumulated on the potting medium ensures better plant health. Since this species grows in a compact rosette form, maintaining its natural shape usually requires little intervention."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"little nipple cactus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["little nipple cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Mammillaria meiacantha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19801,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Iris savannarum, commonly known as the prairie iris, prefers consistent moisture in its growing environment. It thrives in conditions similar to marshes or wet prairies, so the soil should be kept moist at all times, particularly during its growing season in spring and summer. However, ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which may lead to root rot. Reduce watering slightly in the dormant winter period, but never allow the soil to completely dry out. Regular monitoring of soil moisture levels will help maintain optimal watering conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris savannarum thrives best with full sun exposure, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure robust growth and vibrant blooms. This amount of light is essential for performing optimal photosynthesis, which contributes to the plant's health and flowering potential. While it can tolerate partial shade, particularly in regions with very hot summers, insufficient sunlight may lead to fewer flowers and leggy growth. Therefore, selecting a planting site with ample sunlight will yield the best results and maintain the plant's vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Iris savannarum should generally occur after the flowering period has ended. As flowers fade, spent blooms can be snipped off using a clean, sharp pair of scissors or pruners, which helps to direct energy away from seed production and towards the plant's rhizomes for next year's growth. It's crucial to ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry, hot periods. Make sure the top layer of soil (about 1 inch) begins to dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering. In high humidity areas, Torenia may require less frequent watering as the environment provides some moisture. In containers, ensure there's adequate drainage and be particularly vigilant about maintaining consistent moisture levels without waterlogging the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Torenia crustacea thrives in partial shade to full shade environments. It prefers bright, indirect sunlight and can tolerate some morning sun, but intense afternoon rays can scorch the leaves and inhibit flower production. In very hot climates, providing a location that receives filtered sunlight or dappled shade throughout the day is ideal to prevent heat stress. When grown indoors, place it near a window where it receives plenty of indirect light. Overexposure to direct sunlight should be avoided to maintain lush, vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Torenia crustacea primarily involves removing spent blooms to encourage new growth and extend the blooming season. Deadheading regularly will redirect the plant's energy towards producing more flowers instead of seed production. Additionally, trim any dead or damaged leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetic appeal. In late autumn, once flowering has ceased, a more substantial cutback can be performed if the plant is being overwintered indoors. This practice helps to maintain a compact shape and promotes vibrant growth in the next season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brittle False Pimpernel","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Africa"],"other_name":["Brittle False Pimpernel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Torenia crustacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

A good rule of thumb is to water when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leptosiphon chrysanthus thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is adapted to sunny, dry conditions, and full sunlight will support abundant flowering and healthy growth. However, in extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat stress. Ensure it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal blooms. Partial shade may be necessary if the plant appears stressed by too much sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leptosiphon chrysanthus is generally minimal. It can benefit from light trimming after its flowering period to maintain a compact shape and encourage bushier growth. Remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged stems to enhance the plant's appearance and health. Regularly check for any signs of pests or disease and prune those areas as soon as they are noticed. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant and reduce its ability to thrive in harsh conditions."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"golden linanthus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["golden linanthus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Leptosiphon chrysanthus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19804,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Telmatoblechnum serrulatum enjoys consistently moist soil conditions, similar to its natural swampy habitat. It is important to ensure the soil does not dry out, so regular watering is vital. The plant should be watered when the top inch of soil feels dry. During hot or dry periods, increase the frequency of watering. However, avoid waterlogging, as excessive standing water can cause root rot. Utilizing well-draining soil and pots with drainage holes can help balance moisture levels effectively. Be wary of using extremely hard water, as it may affect the plant's health over time."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Telmatoblechnum serrulatum thrives in environments that mimic the forest floor, preferring partial to full shade. It can tolerate morning sun but should be protected from harsh afternoon sunlight to prevent leaf scorch or stress. When growing indoors, place the plant in a location with ample indirect light, possibly near a north or east-facing window. If there is too much direct light, consider using sheer curtains to diffuse it. This plant can survive in low-light conditions but grows best with moderate light exposure. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even growth. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Telmatoblechnum serrulatum should focus on maintaining health and shape. Regularly remove dead or damaged fronds to encourage new growth and prevent disease. Pruning can be done at any time of the year, but it's ideal after the active growth season, which is typically in spring and summer. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage and disease spread. Beyond removing unhealthy fronds, minimal pruning is needed since the plant naturally grows in an attractive, upright manner. Keeping the center open can help with better airflow, reducing potential disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"toothed midsorus fern","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States","Caribbean","Central America","South America"],"other_name":["toothed midsorus fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Spores"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Telmatoblechnum serrulatum"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
